Fields.DialogueText: Kapitän? You're looking pensive. Stimmt etwas nicht?
I hope not. We've received new orders - they want us in the North Atlantic.
If they've ordered us to help the British patrol Jutland I may vomit.
Not this time. I was hoping I could get us stationed around the Wadden Sea so you could... I don't know, have some home time. But apparently we're wanted along the Norwegian coast.
So they're confident Gävle is saved? Stockholm is secure? They do know that Nixen are still massed in the north of the Gulf of Bothnia, ja?

Fields.MenuText: Honestly, I think they're back to worrying about having you too close to Danzig.
All I know is we have our orders.
You know, you look really good today. Did you do something to your hair?
I'm not saying it's fair.
Knowing it's a problem is the first step to fixing it.
I know. I'm not happy about leaving Gävle so soon, either.

Fields.DialogueText: For what it's worth, I'm sorry.
Ja, ja. I suppose a change in climate might be good for morale, regardless.
No more than usual! And you... you've cleaned up well. Maybe it's the light.
*sigh*
Kapitän, if you'll excuse me, I have arrangements to make before we depart.
The new shoes?
Das ist... nicht ganz richtig. I can't get what I need at Gävle - not now - but perhaps I can get something I can trade for what I need elsewhere. Planning, you see?
In principle.
... Kapitän? We're receiving a call for help. The capital ships may be gone, but-
Right. I'll meet you on the bridge!
@BATTLE
Hm? Sorry. I was just - never mind. What were you saying?
Is something wrong?
And what's happening here when we leave? Dare I ask?
Destroyers and minesweepers resume their patrols, I presume. The old routine.

Fields.MenuText: No, I think we're both just very attractive people.
That must be it.
You're much too kind.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't be ridiculous. You're my best ally in all this. Don't think I don't know it.
Ja. Genau. Once again, you see to the heart of the matter.
Nein - I'm charming. It's not the same thing at all.
Unless it's not.
Kapitän? I didn't expect to see you out here.
Brauchen Sie etwas? Or are you just taking in the view?
Well, I figured this is about as close to Danzig as we're going to get, and I know that's complicated for you. I thought I'd see if you wanted some company.
... I had the nightmares again last night.
Sorry to hear it. Any chance it would help to talk about them?
... So, you never said - did you get whatever it was you mean to trade for shoes?
Ah, ja! A crate of toothbrushes!
Toothbrushes?
Ja. Only slightly defective!
Pardon?
I mean to have fun with this, Kapitän.
... Well, that's not unsettling at all.
One moment. We have company. I think we should kill them all quickly so that no one blames me for summoning them.
@BATTLE
I think you should tell me how beautiful I am instead. Much more therapeutic for both of us in the long run.

Fields.MenuText: You were the one who brought the nightmares up.
You're gorgeous. But don't change the subject.
I mean, if you insist.

Fields.DialogueText: It's almost rude of you to point that out, Kapitän.
Too late. The subject has already been changed.
I do.

Fields.MenuText: You're like a full moon reflected in deep, still waters.
You're at least the fifth most attractive woman on this ship.
... Okay, I'm not actually good at this.

Fields.DialogueText: ... What.
On a good day, in the top three.
You're birdsong on the wind.
You're at the back of my imagination from the moment I get up to the moment I close my eyes, and on my luckiest nights I dream of you in between.
We can work on that.
I'm glad you're amusing yourself.
I can keep this going for hours.

Fields.MenuText: So there.
And, before you ask, I'm not going to tell you who I stole that from.
Too florid?

Fields.DialogueText: Please don't.
Yay?
Nein. Not at all.
Wie bedauerlich! You were doing so well!
Heh.
Seriously. Are you okay?
Ja. Natürlich.
Danzig is just... complicated for me. But you know that.
Yeah.
But your story with this place isn't over. I've said it before, and I'll keep on saying it. You'll work it all out in the end.
And you know that how?

Fields.MenuText: I'm the Captain. I know things.
Because I know you.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah.
We were under the impression that the Skagerrak Strait had been successfully blockaded. By the British.
Well, either there are holes in their nets, or the Morganas came from the east.
From Our side, Kapitän? Bite your tongue!

Fields.MenuText: As far as I know, nobody's maintained a blockade against these things for more than a couple of weeks.
Consider my tongue bitten.
Don't take it personally. We were doing our thing in the west Baltic, but that wasn't the only problem area.

Fields.DialogueText: We believe the British must have done a worse job than many.
Sehr gut.
We still prefer to blame the British.
Of course you do.
Regardless, Morganas have been active from Bornholm to Ystad to Rügen. Dealing with them isn't our mission, but it's on the way.
And they might one day threaten Kiel and Lübeck. We do take that personally.
I've been meaning to ask if you wanted to stop in at Kiel before we moved to the Atlantic. You haven't actually been to territorial Schleswig-Holstein since you woke up, have you?
Nein. We... shall consider it. For now?
Are they almost in range?
Ja.
Then, by all means - call the crew to action stations.
@BATTLE
Would it be... do you think it would be selfish to go there? The enemy follows us - they always have.
We can't avoid ports indefinitely, Sophie. It's great when we can salvage fuel and ammo from the enemy, but even if that was guaranteed we need food.
And Kiel's one of the better-guarded ports out there these days.
But it's... nein, never mind.
No, go on.
Kapitän, I just... they're proud of me there. Across the whole state of Schleswig-Holstein. And it's easy to be their hero when I'm not bringing the enemy to their doorstep, but-
Ach, I don't know what I'm saying.

Fields.MenuText: You don't want to let them down.
You don't want the personal attention.
You don't want to appear in public until you have new shoes.

Fields.DialogueText: Natürlich! You get me, Kapitän.
You know I love personal attention. Just... on my own terms.
I'm afraid I already have.
Nope. That's enough of that. Captain's orders.
Look, ultimately, you can't control what the people of Schleswig-Holstein make of you. All you can do is to do your job and trust that it's making the world a better place. People will notice, and-
*sigh*
Morganas?
Ja.
You're probably lucky. Sinking them seems to be better for your morale than my stupid speeches.
I love your stupid speeches. The more stupid the better.
@BATTLE
Thanks.
It's always nice to visit your quarters, Kapitän. They seem so much more welcoming than mine, somehow.

Fields.MenuText: I assume part of it is that I'm always happy to see you.
Fond memories of sleeping on my floor?
Is there a problem? Should we find another space for you?

Fields.DialogueText: That's very kind of you to say.
It's just the truth.
You joke, but... ja. A little bit. Perhaps it was like camping trips for me.
Well, it's no trouble to sweep up your space if you ever need to crash here again.
Nein, nein.
It just feels ridiculous to have quarters in the first place. It's a waste of space that our crew could use for other things.
And yet not a single member of the crew has shown any indication of wanting to complain.
Relax. You'll get used to it.
Ha! You're very kind, Kapitän.
Wenn Sie das sagen.
So, I guess I should ask - is this a social call, or is there ship's business we should be talking about?
Es ist... etwas kompliziert.
Complicated how?
It's about going to Kiel.
Kapitän! They're almost in range!
I know, I know!
I thought there were only supposed to be a few destroyers out here, dammit!
@BATTLE
Sophie? Are you all right?
Ja, Kapitän. We... I now believe that visiting Kiel would be wise. If nothing else, we're running low on fuel.

Fields.MenuText: The indignity of being a Belle with a special diet.
Understood.
Shall we radio ahead and tell them you won't be needing a parade?

Fields.DialogueText: Bitte.
Danke, Kapitän.
Don't start.
I'm looking forward to offloading the toothbrushes, at least.
Nein. Or... well, if we find a foreign ship with something interesting, perhaps. But I will not play games with the people of Kiel.
Forgive me if this is out of line, but... if you're not enjoying this trading game for its own sake, I'd be happy to get you a pair of shoes as a gift.
Or as a special reward from a grateful captain for extraordinary service in battle, if that's less awkward.
I *am* enjoying the trading game for its own sake, Kapitän. And I dare say the Neutrality Fleet isn't paying you enough for you to be wasting your money on kind gestures.

Fields.MenuText: Haven't you noticed I mostly trade on prestige?

Fields.DialogueText: Heh. Even so.

Fields.MenuText: It's not a waste if it makes you happy.

Fields.DialogueText: I disagree. But I'm grateful for the sentiment.

Fields.MenuText: Is that a polite way to avoid saying you don't trust my sense of style?

Fields.DialogueText: If so, then an honest answer would be completely counterproductive, don't you think?
Enjoying the view?
Ja. Kiel is... it's beautiful.

Fields.MenuText: Yes. It is.
I'm not sure this is the most flattering view, actually - but I'm glad you like it.
Uh... okay. I was going to say it's taken a beating, but if you're happy I'm happy.

Fields.DialogueText: We've seen ports that have been harder hit. Somehow the enemy seems more drawn to Copenhagen than Kiel.
I do. Ich mag es sehr.
We got a call while you've been out here, I'm sorry to say. There've been some sightings on the far side of the Fehmarn Belt.
I know. I overheard. I just wanted to look around one more time while we prepared to go.
I don't suppose you unloaded the toothbrushes.
Ja! I did! Remind me to show you the Nona Lisa when the shooting stops!
The what now?
@BATTLE
It's a fake, obviously.
It's not even a good fake. But it's like her eyes follow you.
It's a contemporary reinterpretation of the original Mona Lisa, you savages. It isn't even abstract.
Seriously, it's disturbing to look at.
Do you think it's an accident that it looks like she has gangrene on her hands?
Well, it's the best We could get in exchange for the crate of defective toothbrushes, and though the craftsmanship is... idiosyncratic....
As God is my witness, I think that's a river of lava behind her shoulders. Is this supposed to be hell?
... We remain confident that We can barter it for something that brings Us closer to the shoes We desire.
If it *is* hell, it would explain the grimace.
Devils chewing off her feet?
Exactly.
We are disappointed to learn that neither of you understands fine culture.

Fields.MenuText: Just some gentle humor, Sophie.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja. To hold back the fear.

Fields.MenuText: We could try to stuff it in the depth charge thrower and send it to the Morganas.

Fields.DialogueText: Nein.
I'd be willing to talk to some of our brain trust and-
NEIN.

Fields.MenuText: Disappointed, but presumably not surprised.

Fields.DialogueText: We are pleased to find that you're not lacking in insight, at least.
*ALARM*
Morganas?
Ja.
And you couldn't warn us you were going to sound the alarm?
You were having such a good time mocking the Nona Lisa. We thought it would be cruel to interrupt.
*sigh*
@BATTLE
I think everything about this has to be intentional. It takes a kind of genius to be so... subtly nightmarish.
Sind Sie wach, Kapitän? I don't mean to bother you if you're sleeping.
No worries. If I were sleeping, the door would be closed.
Not at all. Are you having a bad night?
Not particularly. I just feel like staying awake a bit longer.
Nein. I... I'll meet you on the bridge.
@BATTLE
Am I interrupting important business?

Fields.MenuText: No.
It honestly wouldn't matter if you were.
I'm reviewing your reports.

Fields.DialogueText: Das ist unnötig. There's nothing to review. They're flawless, so they don't need correction, and I've already talked to you about everything in them anyway.
Das ist gut. I don't want to be a burden to you.
If not for you, I'd be out here swimming.
Hm.
Can I get you something to drink? I have... um... water. But I wouldn't have to go too far to get something more exciting.
Nein. Danke.
Do you mind if I close it behind me?
... Kapitän, I know you technically outrank me--
"Technically?"
Ja. The power balance between us... it's more complicated than between you and, say, Walther. You outrank me, but you're human and I'm what I am.
I have real power over you, and I would not want to misuse it - or put you in a compromising position.
... Okay.
But I see the way you look at me when you think I'm not watching.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry about that. It's unprofessional.
In fairness, it's how I look at you when you *are* watching too.
So you're looking at me, too? That's promising.

Fields.DialogueText: Nein. It's no burden.
Ja. I suppose it is.
Is it?
Kapitän... I don't think I can be who you want me to be.
I don't-
But I-
Sorry. You first.
... The enemy is approaching.
You're kidding.
So... I hear we've parted ways with the Nona Lisa?
Ah! Ja. Our procurement specialist worked his special magic and arranged for a trade with a supply ship headed for Britain.
My heart is a little bit broken.
That's the power of great art, Kapitän.
Clearly. Should I ask what you got in exchange? Shoes?
A goat. And a potato that looks like Herr Mussolini.

Fields.MenuText: ... Yes, that follows.
Please tell me we're not keeping the goat.
You realize that the potato's natural market is a long way from the North Sea, right?

Fields.DialogueText: If I wanted this to be easy, I would've just bought shoes in Kiel, Kapitän.
I'm not planning to. Though I believe it's infatuated with Walther, and I do hate to interfere with young love.
Noted.
You realize, of course, that we're quite close to where the Battle of Jutland took place. I wonder what Admiral Hipper - the Belle, I mean - would make of it.

Fields.MenuText: I gather she remembers her namesake's career fairly vividly.
She wasn't here. You were. What do *you* make of it?

Fields.DialogueText: Sehr gut.
I just fired more rounds outside of Kiel than I ever did here. I think I'm happier talking about our new goat.
Hey. Do you see something? Over there, northwest-ish.
Mein Gott, nostalgia will be the death of me. Good eyes, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
Sophie. Hi.
Kapitän. I... I know things were left unsaid the last time we talked. But...
No, I'm not proposing to resume the conversation here on the deck. You can relax.
I'm always relaxed, Kapitän.
Uh-huh.
You should try to be kinder to Gunther, Walther.
It should try to stop eating my shirt.
From a goat, that's a sign of affection.
It's a sign that they were feeding it English food on that other ship and it thinks cotton is a step up.
Both can be true.

Fields.MenuText: We do have English crew. Let's stop the gratuitous insults.
You think your transitional League uniform is made of cotton?
Just be glad it doesn't have a taste for human flesh.

Fields.DialogueText: ... We regretfully concede the point.
Oh, please, don't take this conversation into the majestic plural. We're talking about a goat eating Voss' clothes.
I'm honestly completely ignorant about fabrics, Kapitän. I'm just reasonably confident my shirt isn't Hessisch.
Sie haben Recht, Kapitän. I'm not sure I could say the same about the painting.
It wasn't that bad.
Respectfully, it absolutely was that bad.
*sigh*
Right. Was that a sigh of exasperation at us, or are there enemies incoming?
Again, both can be true.
So they can.
I'll meet you on the bridge, Kapitän.
You know, it may not be my place to say, but - she's happier since you came onboard, Kapitän. Thank you for that.
... Okay. Thank you for saying so.
The fact that you're helping to keep us alive has got to be a factor, by the way. Keep it up.
Heh.
@BATTLE
The distress call hasn't been repeated in almost an hour.
Nein. There's been no sign of the fishing boats, nor of the destroyer meant to protect them. We may be too late to rescue anyone, Kapitän. But We might at least avenge.
Agreed.
I don't suppose I need to say it, but - be alert for bombers. If the reports are correct, they apparently leveled the one church in Utsira just for laughs.
Utsira is...?
Norwegian island. Sparsely populated. No military targets at all, as far as I can tell. It's just gratuitous.
Maybe they have something against consecrated ground?

Fields.MenuText: I wouldn't be surprised.
I don't know. I've had priests bless shells before I shoot at them and it hasn't made any obvious difference.
I don't care. I just want them gone.

Fields.DialogueText: Regardless, ja. We're looking out for bombers.
... And we're not spotting them.
Nein.

Fields.MenuText: Nothing for it but patience, I suppose.
The waiting is the worst part of this damn war.
I may go get some coffee. Anybody want anything?

Fields.DialogueText: Ugh.
Das stimmt.
Nein, danke.
... How's the goat treating you, Walther?
*sigh*
Just don't let the damn goat follow you back. Bitte.
Depends on how desperate I get for distraction.
I'm here, Sophie. What's the word - have we made contact with the Morgana carrier group?
Nein. Or, at least, We shouldn't think so. They were heading north-northeast from Utsira; we're being approached by a group that seems to be coming from the northwest.
That tracks. There's been word that they've been raiding Shetland and the Orkneys.
We assume that the Scots and the British would not welcome Our assistance.
They'll let us know if they need it. Right now our brief is Norway - and self-defense, of course.
So gracious of the League!

Fields.MenuText: Dial back the sarcasm. The League's on our side.
Well, however they feel about you, they probably want to keep *me* alive.
Stamping your foot at the end was a nice touch. Very dramatic.

Fields.DialogueText: It was good of you to notice.
Vielleicht they are. We believe you believe it, at least.
You're being glib, but that is actually of some comfort.
Any other news?
We fear that Potato Mussolini has come to an ugly end.
Say it's not so.
Some of the men were trying to replicate another Schiffsdame's experiments with a weapon that launches potatoes at great speed. Potato Mussolini gave his life for science.
Did it work?
It did not. There was quite a mess on Our deck.
Sorry to hear it.
@BATTLE
Ja. It's very sad.
You know... the other day, Walther said something about you being happier since I got here.
He might be more clever than We give him credit for.
So... you haven't been avoiding me the past couple of days?
You know it's been hectic, Kapitän.
That wasn't a "nein."
... You're clever too.
If I offended you--
Nein! Never!
Well... let me know if you ever want to talk, then. After the shooting stops, obviously.
Kapitän?
Sophie! Hi! How are you?
Mir geht es sehr gut. I've been watching crew members trying to make Walther kiss the goat - it's been very good for my morale.

Fields.MenuText: Oh... kay.
Is that a euphemism for something I should know about?
Ha! Where? Why was I not told?

Fields.DialogueText: They hope it will bring good luck.
Nein, nein. They hope it will bring good luck.
I looked for you! But you were... indisposed.
Isn't that always the way? So, they were torturing him because...?
That follows, yes.
... Listen, when you said you couldn't be who I wanted you to be-
I thought you said we weren't going to have this conversation on the deck.
Yeah. I thought we'd have had it somewhere else by now.
I like you. A lot. And the last thing I want is for you to be uncomfortable around me. I think maybe the thing to do is just agree to say that we never had that conversation.
Everything just goes back to normal, and you don't need to worry about me bringing up anything you don't want to deal with. The war's complicated enough as it is.
What? Are Morganas coming?
Ja. Ja, they are. We should deal with those.
Right. I'll see you on the bridge.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: In my case, pretty good.
In my case, glasses would help.
I can barely see *you*.

Fields.DialogueText: I can tell something's out there - and I can make out hills in the background, I think - but not a whole lot else.
Schade. I look amazing.
... It's very quiet.
Mm.
"Mm?"
@BATTLE
Is that Bergen over there? In the mist?
Ja. Or... well, Bergen *is* over there in the mist. I've never been quite sure how good human eyes are.
Nicht für lange. Maybe you should get to the bridge.
Hold on. Are you angry with me now?
Nein.
Sophie. Come on.
Kapitän, this is... actually, ja, this is why I said it wouldn't work between us. I'm not flirty and fun. Not really. I just... I know how to follow orders, and I know how to blow things up.
You were right to put all that nonsense from before behind us.
And now we really should go to the bridge. Ich werde Sie dort treffen.
Sophie? Sophie!
Dammit.
Hey, Bergen has been good to you! You got shoes in exchange for the goat?
Nein. Boots.
Well, they're good for the cold. It's definitely getting sharper out on the water.
Ja, ich weiß. I'm floating in the stuff.
Looks like there should be a hundred or more in that crate. We can distribute them among the crew, maybe - after you take your pick.
Kapitän, I told you, they're boots. I wanted shoes for dancing, not big slabs of leather for stomping through the muck.
Dancing?
Ja. It was silly.
Was? What are you looking at?
Are these all left boots?
Ja.
All of them?
You think I could get fifty pairs of boots for a goat? Even a lucky goat? Nein, these are all defective lefties.
They're for trade. Hopefully someone can use the leather.
This does complicate my Charleston plan.
Sophie?
Aircraft. Aircraft! Kapitän, we've been spotted - the carrier group!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: There's a place for silly, even in wartime. Maybe especially in wartime.
No. That isn't silly at all.
So what? It's your money. Or weird trades, I guess.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, regardless - right now I have boots.
Tell you what. Let's find pairs in both our sizes and dance badly in them.
What? Nein.
Trust me, if I'm dancing next to you, nobody in the crew is going to be laughing at *you*. Get a few jazz records playing - hey, have you ever done the Charleston?
Ha! I'm offended by the very idea!
That just means you haven't... wait.
Kapitän? Darf ich rein kommen? Are you awake?
Sure. Come in.
Danke. Tell me about the Charleston.
The dance?
Ja! You were talking about it the other day. Have you done it? Do you know how?

Fields.MenuText: It's actually an older dance style - before my time. I can show you how to Lindy Hop.
No, but I'll fake it if you ask nicely.
Yeah - but, trust me, there's not enough room in here.

Fields.DialogueText: Nein, nein. It's all right. Not now, anyway.

Fields.MenuText: I *would* like to dance with you sometime.
Then I guess I need to find some other way to entertain you.
Whew.

Fields.DialogueText: Do I need to get new shoes for you, too?
Double the Nona Lisas and double the goats? No, thanks - I'll make do with what I've already got.
I'll pretend I didn't hear that.
I have faith in your resourcefulness, Kapitän.
So... how are you? Any lasting ill effects from that run-in with the carrier the other day?
Eugh. I hate bombers.
Perfectly understandable.
... Do you get lonely, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: Sure.
I'm in command. It wouldn't be appropriate to admit it if I did.
How could I? You're always here for me.

Fields.DialogueText: But, Sophie, what's going on? You're bouncing all over the place.
Ja. Because I've been worrying about this conversation for weeks.
Kapitän, I think we have clearly established that I'm not... that, realistically, I would be a terrible "girlfriend." But if you need companionship - distraction - then I would...
Why are you looking at me like that?
Because I'm trying to figure out what you think being "a girlfriend" means so I can understand why you think you'd be terrible at it!

Sophie, it's like the first thing you think is that you don't deserve to have anybody care for you, and you're expecting me to just agree with it so we can get on to... whatever else you have in mind.
You're angry with me.
No.
I should go.
No, you shouldn't.
Sophie, I don't know what's going on in your head. I think you're making some things more complicated than they have to be, but I'm just guessing.
But I hope you know that I like you. A lot. And I hope you know you can talk to me about what you want from us. Because, among other reasons, I may want it too.
Maybe I want to declare myself Kaiserin of Danzig and you my First Admiral.
Heh. Would I get a better uniform than this one?
Without question, Kapitän. Unlike the Neutrality Fleet, I have standards.
Harsh, but fair.
... Kapitän, I've gotten into the habit of leaning on you. Constantly. You give and I take. I don't like that about myself.
I wouldn't either, if it were true.
Warrior spirit in a human body?
Yeah. Yeah, something like that. You do more than anybody to make me feel like all this--
*ALARM*
Did you do that?
Nein. Nein, we're not alone - but I didn't see it! Mein Gott, I'm getting more careless by the day!
Hey, it's why we have lookouts.
@BATTLE
Sophie, there are times when it seems like you're the only person on this ship who talks to me like I'm a human being, and not just some...
Kapitän, We are quite confident of the enemy fleet's course. They are withdrawing from the Norwegian coastline and aiming for Scotland.
We'll be able to intercept before they reach British waters?
This group? Ja. Natürlich. But you know there have been reports of others.
I know.  But the British government has told the League in no uncertain terms that they want us hugging the fjords instead of chasing the enemy to Scapa Flow.
Because they're afraid I'm a doomsday weapon that summons Nixen.

Fields.MenuText: You should keep using "we" when talking about how people view this ship.
It doesn't matter what they think. Right? We know better.
Or they're at war with Germany on land and seizing on a pretext to keep a battleship away.

Fields.DialogueText: But it isn't the crew people blame, is it? It's me.
It matters if they won't let us help.
The preposterous thing is that that idea actually makes me feel a little bit better.
I know it's ridiculous, and we'll work on it - but stay focused, Sophie. Things are going to get hectic in a minute.
Hmpf. When have I ever let you down, Kapitän?
You do keep running off to shoot Morganas whenever our conversations start getting interesting.
Aber, aber. I think that's one of the things you like about me.
@BATTLE
I mean, you *do* make it look good.
It's getting colder.
Ja. It's Norway - and not southern Norway at that. We're not so far from the Arctic Circle.
Still, it's come on really quickly. I wonder if it's a Morgana weather thing.
Kapitän, it's the far north. It gets cold. Don't overthink things.
You know what would take your mind off the cold?

Fields.MenuText: Warmth?
You're going to tell me Morganas are incoming, aren't you?
I like the way this conversation is going.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja! Because you like dancing!
You know Princess Helena Augusta Victoria had a waltz named after her? A mark of honor from a more civilized age.
Probably. But not quite yet.
Okay. What, then?
Sehr witzig.
Dancing forces you to be in the moment. The music channels you. You have an obligation to your partner to be joyful - but precise.
For as long as the dance continues, you are in service to it, and nothing else matters.
Ah.
Morganas?
Ja.
We'll get back to those dancing plans later, Sophie. I promise.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I do.
I don't remember ever actually saying that.
I don't, but if makes you happy I'll try to keep quiet about it.

Fields.DialogueText: Dancing! You like dancing, Kapitän, oder?
We really have to get you those shoes, huh?
We will. And when we do-
Nein! Oh Gott, nein!
That sounds ominous.
I traded away the left boots to that freighter headed for Tromsø, Kapitän. Apparently Walther misses them desperately.
Look at this, Kapitän! Look at what she traded them for!
You need to show the ship's Belle a little bit more respect, sailor. It-
... That's the Nona Lisa again.
Improved. Our British friends restored it.
They drew a mustache on it!
Ja. Like the Reichskanzler's. An intriguing artistic choice.

Fields.MenuText: A bit of political commentary, Sophie?

Fields.DialogueText: Whisper, Kapitän. Let's not get the SS moles onboard all excited.

Fields.MenuText: That actually makes it even more disturbing.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja. Ja, it does!
Don't worry. Their duties generally keep them sidelined.

Fields.MenuText: This seems like a step down. Unless you got a potato that looks like Churchill.

Fields.DialogueText: Ach, nein. Fortune was not that much on our side.
Danke, Walther.
Listen, if your end goal was to get me to offer to buy you shoes in exchange for throwing this thing overboard...
It's working! Take my paycheck!
An attractive offer. But...
I know that look.
Yeah. So do I. I take it they're reasonably close, Sophie?
We can catch them within the hour if we push the engines.
Let's do that, then.
@BATTLE
You had word from the League at Tromsø, Kapitän?
Not formally. But unnamed individuals wanted us to know that Morgana activity around northern Scotland really has been picking up.
Are they making a move on Scapa Flow?
No - though I gather there have been some close calls with submarines.
They seem to be more interested in scaring the hell out of the populations of the Orkney Islands. And Shetland.
Which is, what, four shepherds and their flocks?

Fields.MenuText: A bit more than that.
Not a laughing matter, Sophie.
If so, by God, they're human shepherds, and the Morganas can't have them.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja. You're right, of course.
Are we supposed to get involved? Will the League back us if we do?
If we do, they'd *better* back us. I understand political concerns, but the Neutrality Fleet won't work if we can't help where we're needed.
... Kapitän? I think we may have just gotten lucky.
That would be a pleasant change. What's up?
Slow-moving Morgana. Slow-moving Avarice, in fact. I think.
Slow-moving, as in weighed down?
Ich glaube, das könnte sein.
Okay, then. I'll meet you on the bridge.
@BATTLE
Hm. I know I was the one to ask the question, but... the League needs you more than you need the League. You'll find a way to make it work.

Fields.MenuText: I hope so.
"We." Not just me.
You don't need to flatter me, Sophie.

Fields.DialogueText: But you like it?
I will neither confirm nor deny.
Nein, this time, I think it really is mostly you.
Let's agree to disagree.
The powers that be in Denmark have given us a go-ahead to take a detour to the Faroe Islands before we head back south.
I can sway. And if we happen to pull Morganas away from Shetland as we pass, completely inadvertently, I trust the British government will forgive us.
I don't think I care about the British government right now.
@BATTLE
Sophie! Come in. It's good to-
Is that the Nona Lisa?
Under a blanket, ja. You don't actually have to look at it.
Okay, but why is it here?
Housewarming present?
Never mind. Just... put it down somewhere were I won't be tempted to burn it.
I can sit down and hold it on my lap.
Please don't.
Ha!
Danke, dass Sie mich eingeladen haben, Kapitän. The written invitation was a nice touch.
I thought you might be sleeping, so something written... yeah, never mind. You're welcome.
Anyway, if you're willing, I thought I would ask you to show me how to do that waltz. Princess Helena Augusta Victoria's dance.
Ja?
Yeah.
Sehr gut! Stand up straight! Your left hand in my right hand - we hold them about level with my eyes.
Got it.
Ja. Your right hand on my back, there at the shoulder blade. My hand on your shoulder, so.
Am I going to be able to move without breaking my knees on your gun skirts?
I promise I'll be gentle with you, Kapitän.
Okay. Are you going to start, or...?
Nein. I want you to stand like this. Get used to holding me.

Fields.MenuText: I can do that.
I think I love dancing.
But I feel like the painting is judging us.

Fields.DialogueText: I can see that.
I'm fond of it myself.
Hush.
Um. While we stand here - we have some slightly new orders.
Interesting. But, Kapitän, imagine music playing. Just... sway with me as you speak.
Hey, me either.
Kapitän?
Yes?
The enemy is approaching.
OH SON OF A--
Sophie? What's going on?
A small, contained fire, Kapitän. Some of the crew on the deck petitioned for a chance to warm their hands.
... But they're burning the Nona Lisa.
Flammable materials *are* relatively rare, Kapitän.
You let them do it?
I let them buy it from me. That means it's theirs to do with as they please.

Fields.MenuText: ... Was this your plan all along?
I wouldn't want to breathe those fumes in.
I mean, I contributed to the destruction fund. I just somehow thought you'd find a way to stop it.

Fields.DialogueText: Why, Kapitän. Ich weiß nicht, was Sie meinen. How could there be a plan?
Nein, I wouldn't think paint fumes and human lungs would make for a healthy combination.
Plus, Walther tells me on good authority that the paint is probably cursed.
Das geht schon in Ordnung!
I don't know. I'm just a simple, ordinary human. How could I possibly grasp the plans of Belles?
Well said.
I mean, unless you painted the thing yourself, never traded it in the first place, and made a point of egging Voss on into making a cause of getting rid of it.
And the left shoes?
People can use the leather. And the rubber. And you do have your own money.
Interesting theory, Kapitän. And Gunther the goat?
But, that said, you don't mind seeing the thing burn?
Nein. It was *very* ugly.

Fields.MenuText: Yes. Yes, it was.
... Damn it, now I'm feeling kind of protective of it.

Fields.DialogueText: *sigh* I'm afraid you need to get over it, Kapitän. Quickly.
Done. We talking about Morganas?
Ja.
I'll meet you on the bridge.
@BATTLE
Getting a scared animal to safety while screwing with Walther's head?
I have to say, that *does* sound like something I would enjoy even more than playing games with a painting.
Kapitän, I think we are now technically in British waters.
Unfortunately, we are now also legitimately responding to the sound of Morgana guns.
Is that Unst? Over there?
Ja, I think it must be.
I have no idea what the verdammten Nixen could be targeting. Do they hate sheep?
They could be trying to lure us in.
A trap?

Fields.MenuText: I know, it seems unlikely. They may just be testing their targeting systems.
Better safe than sorry.
Does it matter?

Fields.DialogueText: It would be more satisfying to sink them all if it were a trap.
Fair enough. Whatever happens, we'll call it a trap.
If it *is* a trap, there's a remote chance it's political - a bid to make you seem responsible for loss of British lives and property.
To that end, I want somebody documenting every shot we take and every action we make so it's clear we're on the up and up. Let's be perfect, people.
Either way...
Yeah, it's time to stop them.
Sehr gut, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
And, Sophie, I know I don't need to tell you to be careful and to take care of yourself, but...
Ja. You, too.
The Shetland fishermen are on their way back to shore, Kapitän? I can sense more Nixen coming.
They're almost back to land already. And they're thrilled we're here, German ship or not - Morganas have been harassing them for weeks in groups of one or two.
If they're clustering together to get us, and we're sinking them promptly, these people might have a window of relative normalcy.
And, if not, it's just a German battleship that's been sunk. No great loss.

Fields.MenuText: They were a little more tactful than that.
They were actually astonished that a German ship would want to help *them*.
Can you blame them? The land war is what it is.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja. And I have to believe it will all work out in the end.
Well, now I wish I'd listened in on the conversation. Did you tell them I was beautiful as well as selfless?
I'm relieved to hear it.
I should add that they brought you a present. Technically a present from me, but...
Kapitän, you have my full attention.
Behold: shoes. Unused, before you ask. A young man bought them for a young woman and then their relationship got complicated, as I understand it.
I think they're your size.
Ja, but they're hideous.
But they're comfortable for dancing!
... But they're hideous.
You said that already.
Ja, because clearly you weren't listening.
@BATTLE
If it makes you feel any better, I think they're a lot more attractive than the ones I got for myself.
Nein. You didn't.
Oh, I did. If you're willing to sway around with me once in a while, stuffing my feet into a pair of clown shoes is a small price to pay.
Kapitän, you shouldn't-
If there's you're about to say I shouldn't make sacrifices for you or you're not worth the trouble, stop. Brainstorm new ways to mock me for inflicting those shoes on you instead.
That *is* more fun. But I - ah, verdammt.
The Morganas?
Natürlich.
Well, that's an even better distraction, I guess.
@BATTLE
You weren't joking, Kapitän. Those shoes of yours are... have they been *painted* black?

Fields.MenuText: In six months' time, it'll be all the rage in Kiel.
Yeah, but I make it look good. Right?
Just try not to look at them.

Fields.DialogueText: That almost sounds like you're insulting one of my cities, Kapitän.
I'm so happy you think so! Positivity is so important - good for you!
Wise words, but hard to obey.
Uh-huh. Do you want to dance, or do you want to make fun of my shoes?
Actually... before we do either, I thought I might finally talk about... about what I want. Would that be all right?
Of course it would.
I feel like I shouldn't want anything from you at all, of course. I'm here to serve you and protect you, and... and the one thing gets in the way of the other.
I'm your captain, Sophie. It goes both ways.
It's more than that, Kapitän. We've talked about the Nixen before. I fired the shots that first called them here, and I feel - I know - that I'm going to have to answer for that one day.
No. Before you woke up as a Belle, your commanding officer and crew used your guns to fire on the Westerplatte, and then Morganas appeared.
That wasn't you. It's not your responsibility if it wasn't in your power to do anything else. You're being too hard on yourself.
Kapitän, it's not a matter of what's fair. It's just a matter of what *is*.
I want you to be happy, and I don't see how you can be with me. Not forever.
But... if you want to be with me, I don't think I'm strong enough to push you away. I should be, but you're the best part of my life.

Fields.MenuText: Then how about we don't worry about forever?
The feeling's mutual.
You know what might make you feel better? Kissing.

Fields.DialogueText: Sophie, we're in the middle of a war. Nobody can make long-term plans.
But being with you makes me happy. And if being with me makes you happy, then that seems like something worth protecting, not pushing off to the side.
Was?
As your friend, and as the person whose room you've been sneaking into at night for weeks, I promise you: it's okay to stop torturing yourself. Our lives won't be ruined if you let yourself have fun.
As a wise woman once told me about an unrelated point, you're overthinking things.
And you're being presumptuous.
Yes. And I can get away with it because I'm a great kisser.
Pff.
Go on. Ask me to prove it.
Kapitän...
Sophie, seriously. I care desperately for you, and whatever you want to do I'll go along with. But if you can find it in your heart to-
Das ist genug. Just shut up and kiss me. Okay?
I can do that.
*ALARM*
Hagel un' Granaten!
Wait. We can have thirty more seconds before running to the bridge, can't we?
... Maybe even forty-five.
Last fires are out?
Ja, Kapitän. Finally.
So... can we pick up where we left off?
Remind me where that was.
If you insist...
